chapters.title: Rewterz Threat Advisory VMware VMSA-2022-0014 Actively Exploited

sentences.text: VMware Workspace ONE Access and VMware Identity Manager could allow a local authenticated attacker to gain elevated privileges on the system. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to gain root privileges.
sentences.html: VMware Workspace ONE Access and VMware Identity Manager could allow a local authenticated attacker to gain elevated privileges on the system. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to gain root privileges.

sentences.text: VMware Workspace ONE Access, VMware Identity Manager, and VMware vRealize Automation could allow a remote attacker to bypass security restrictions. By sending a specially-crafted request, an attacker could exploit this vulnerability to obtain administrative access.
sentences.html: VMware Workspace ONE Access, VMware Identity Manager, and VMware vRealize Automation could allow a remote attacker to bypass security restrictions. By sending a specially-crafted request, an attacker could exploit this vulnerability to obtain administrative access.

sentences.text: This is a critical vulnerability. Patch Now!

sentences.text: Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql to see all administrators (readonly administrators also included) and run View-Active-Local-users.sql to see all local users who will be disabled. Make sure that View-Active-Admin-users.sql shows at least 1 provisioned (usually from a Directory) administrator<crlf>Run Disable_All_Local_users.sql to disable all local users and administrators<crlf>Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql to see which administrators now remain active. Only provisioned (usually Directory users) userType administrators should show here.<crlf>Login to Workspace ONE Access/VMware Identity Manager appliance using a sshclient as root user. Restart the service using the command service horizon-workspace restart. Repeat this process for all appliances in your environment.<crlf>Until the hotfixes are applied, do not create any new local users.
sentences.html:
1. Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql to see all administrators (readonly administrators also included) and run View-Active-Local-users.sql to see all local users who will be disabled. Make sure that View-Active-Admin-users.sql shows at least 1 provisioned (usually from a Directory) administrator
  2. Run Disable_All_Local_users.sql to disable all local users and administrators
  3. Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql to see which administrators now remain active. Only provisioned (usually Directory users) userType administrators should show here.
  4. Login to Workspace ONE Access/VMware Identity Manager appliance using a sshclient as root user. Restart the service using the command “service horizon-workspace restart”. Repeat this process for all appliances in your environment.
  5. Until the hotfixes are applied, do not create any new local users.

sentences.text: Use these steps only after applying the Hotfixes or if there is a lock out
sentences.html: Use these steps only after applying the Hotfixes or if there is a lock out

sentences.text: Run Reenable_Disabled_Users.sql to enable the previously disabled users<crlf>Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql and View-Active-Local-users.sql to confirm that local users and administrators have been re-enabled
sentences.html:
1. Run Reenable_Disabled_Users.sql to enable the previously disabled users
  2. Run View-Active-Admin-users.sql and View-Active-Local-users.sql to confirm that local users and administrators have been re-enabled
